cluster_relations.rel_desc: Host plants serve as a food source for the emerging caterpillar (larval) stage.
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Butterfly Host Plants and Larval Resources
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: for emerging larvae, shortly after hatching

remarks: Emerging larvae correspond to the caterpillar larval stage.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Caterpillars help maintain the balance of plant populations.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Caterpillars are described as essential components of the ecosystem.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Basis: roles in pollination and plant population balance

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Adult butterflies serve in the role of a food source.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Butterflies serving as a food source contributes to biodiversity.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject serves as a food resource for the object in a trophic interaction.
args.justification: The relation describes host plants functioning specifically as a food source for emerging caterpillars, which is best captured as a trophic resource predicate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject plays a role in maintaining or stabilizing the object state or process.
args.justification: The description states that caterpillars help maintain the balance of plant populations, which is a causal contribution to the maintenance of that balance.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is an essential component or constituent part of the object system.
args.justification: Caterpillars are described as essential components of the ecosystem, which is a part–whole/system-membership relationship rather than a generic effect.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject has a specified trophic or prey/predator role in an ecosystem (here, serving as a food source).
args.justification: The adult butterfly life stage is said to serve in the role of a food source; this is best modeled as the organism having a particular trophic role.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject has a causal or supporting effect on the emergence, level, or quality of the object.
args.justification: The relation explicitly states that serving as a food source contributes to biodiversity, which is a straightforward causal contribution.
This relation captures a specific trophic resource link where host plants are a food source for larvae, fitting a dedicated trophic resource class rather than a generic ecological effect.

Both relations describe how a biological subject (caterpillars, food source role) causally affects higher-level ecological outcomes (plant population balance, biodiversity). Grouping them as ecological effect relations reflects this shared causal-outcome semantics.

Both relations express the ecological roles of butterflies/caterpillars: being an essential ecosystem component and serving as a food source (trophic role). These naturally belong to a common ecological-role class.
A food-provision link between plants and caterpillars is a classic biotic (trophic) interaction in ecology, best captured under an interaction-oriented group.
Both relations describe causal influences of the subject on an ecological state or outcome (maintenance of plant balance, biodiversity), which aligns with a causality-focused group.
Being an essential component of an ecosystem is a part–whole, system-composition relation, so a composition-oriented group is most appropriate.
Having a trophic role as a food source situates the organism within predator–prey interactions, which is naturally modeled under an interaction group.
